replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Cyndy Cynthia Ashkat --

Thank you for your complete answer!

Couple comments and questions:
Where do you see evidence that marathons are getting shorter?  What is getting shorter?  Take a look at the label on the y-axis to help you respond.
This is a time series graph with only one variable -- time of marathoner.  A scatter plot has two quantitative variables, like height and weight.

Tomorrow, you can get the link to the article that included this graph in the Reveal that will be at the bottom of this feature.  Learn more about the reasons for the faster and faster times.

name: Patrick Hohe
comment info:
"Runner's High-Female Marathoner Edition" 
As I look over the data that this graph is displaying, I notice that every couple years, the average marathon time for a woman improves about one to two minutes. This makes me wonder what causes this improvement...does their training change in terms of difficulty? Do they eat or drink something different during the race itself? We may never know the answer, unless we ask these female athletes. Growing up in a family of runners, including myself, I tend to follow in my family's footsteps when it comes to training, eating+sleeping habits, etc. Beyond that, my family has seen great success in this sport, which makes me curious to what point are these women changing their running-related rituals to gain such impressive times. Do they run 3 workouts a week, rather than 2 workouts a week? Do they snack before a run or workout? Again, going back to my previous comment, we will only know the answers if we ask the athlete experiencing the improvements.

name: Aidan Dolinsky
comment info:
In the graph, the mean time for completion has increased by over 10 minutes. More notably, the gap of talent between the slowest and fastest runners has nearly halved from around 25 to 13 minutes. However, the peak times have not increased. The increase in average times is likely due to increased talent scouting and selection (pooling competitors from more countries, cities, etc) as well as a greater understanding of running biomechanics and training modalities. On the other hand, the top runner is roughly consistent with finishing times - meaning that shattering the previously conceived maximum human potential is very difficult. Genetically, these Women have not evolved - but the  level of competition in the event has. 
This is a shared phenomenon among many sports when the level of human potential is questioned. For example, the average baseball pitch is roughly 10 miles-per-hour faster than it was 20 years ago due to increased training and scouting, but the fastest pitch thrown in history has not changed since 1974.

name: Michael

comment info:
1. The average running speed of the top 50 women marathoners has increased since 2000 (since the average time taken to run the marathon has decreased). This seems to particularly be due to an increase towards the bottom of the spread on the graph.
2. I can think of some potential causes of this, with the broad overview being an increase in the number of women running marathons overtime. Now, with a growing population, that seems obvious, but I wonder if the rate of change in the running speed might be affected by certain factors relating to women's sports in particular. For example, if most women who would be achieving top marathon times would be in their 20s, did the average speed of women running marathons increase faster than usual during the 90s, when the first generations affected by Title IX and the increasing gender parity in school sports reached that age? How does this correlate with standards of living in general? And what do the averages look like for all women finishing marathons?
3. It is certainly heartening to see that athletes are getting fitter over time, though I can't say what this means for gender equality without comparing it to the times for men. Broadly speaking, it's a positive trend.
4. "Top Women Runners Getting Faster" (I tried to be catchy without getting less accurate, but it is a bit vague; I don't know how to make the word "marathon" catchy).

name: Paul CV
comment info:
Women, without doubt, have become more agile when running marathons in the past 20 years. At the start of the century, their range was between 2:47:00 and 2:27:00. Now, their times have dropped to around 2:35:00 through 2:22:00. That means that their maximum time has decreased by nearly 12 minutes and their minimum by 5 minutes. Furthermore, the female's times have become more spread out. Meaning, the dots on the graph have become more dispersed, instead of being concentrated at the maximum times. One other trend I observed is that there were fewer runners recorded in the past couple years. I did some tedious counting and found out that around the start of the graph, there were about 70 athletes, but in the more recent years, about 40 athletes have competed. In summary, women have improved their times for running marathons, however they also have grown to be fewer and farther between. 

I wonder if this tendency also applies to men?

This perseverance and dedication proves to me that it is possible to improve anything, even when I may think it is already flawless.

My graph's headline would be: "Catch Me if You Ever Can".

name: Melina
comment info: Between 2000 to 2019, the 50 fastest women marathoners have unquestionably increased their speed (decreasing their finish time). If you drew a line along the bottom of the graph, it would be a linear, increasing line. The line would start near 2:45:00 in 2000 and end near 2:35:00 in 2019. Which means, the runners decreased their finish time by approximately 10 minutes between those years. There are many outliers near 2:20:00 and the faster times. Specifically at 2012, you can see a major gap between 2:45:00 and about 2:37:00. There were no times above 2:37:00 for 2012. I wonder what occurred that year that created a significant difference in finish times. What did the runners do in preparation to peak in that year? Personally, viewing this graph is inspirational. This shows a major achievement for women and their extreme dedication and resilience. It is incredible that these women have continued to participate in marathons throughout 19 years. That is unbelievable perseverance and commitment. The traits that these women have are some that I value in my own life and wish to develop for the future. Everyone should use this as an example in their life and think about these individuals when things become difficult. A headline that relates to the graph is "Fast Times for Long Distances".

replies.comment info:
Good morning, @Melina --

Thank you for the insightful noticings, wonderings, how this affects you and your community and headline.

name: Sara (CJHS)
comment info:
1. I notice the spread of the graph first. The line of best fit is definitely increasing, leading me to believe that the marathoners are indeed growing faster as time goes on.
2. That said, the first question that pops into my head is, "How?" How do the marathoners increase their stamina and speed so drastically? Evidently, practice does make them better, but this is a great piece of evidence to show HOW MUCH practice can improve on a baseline speed.
3. This helps me realize that just by continuing to push yourself, you can increase your skills exponentially over a given period of time. It shows that while some of the marathon runners increase at different paces, over time it ultimately leads to them becoming better versions of themselves. This can be applied to anything, really: academics, sports, art, music, etc.
4. A catchy headline could be: "Marathoners Make a Move: Practice Really Does Make Perfect."
